docs.lead_paragraph: About 2.7 million people have been newly infected each year for the last five years, according to a report released by the United Nations.

headline.seo: U.N.AIDS Says New Worldwide Infections Have Hit a Plateau
headline.main: New Cases of AIDS Hit Plateau
headline.print_headline: New Cases Of AIDS Hit Plateau

docs.abstract: United Nations releases report which finds world's AIDS epidemic has plateaued, with 2.7 million people becoming newly infected each year for the last five years; almost seven million people are receiving treatment for disease, but treatment rate has so far failed to catch up with rate of new infections.
docs.snippet: About 2.7 million people have been newly infected each year for the last five years, according to a report released by the United Nations.

docs.lead_paragraph: “The Hoarder in You: How to Live a Happier, Healthier, Uncluttered Life,” can help in decluttering a life overrun by needless things.

headline.seo: ‘The Hoarder in You’ - A Book That Can Help Cut Through the Clutter
headline.main: It’s Time to Say Goodbye to All That Stuff
headline.print_headline: It’s Time to Say Goodbye to All That Stuff

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column says book The Hoarder in You: How to Live a Happier, Healthier, Uncluttered Life by clinical psychologist Robin Zasio offers useful advice for anyone who has trouble throwing things away.
docs.snippet: “The Hoarder in You: How to Live a Happier, Healthier, Uncluttered Life,” can help in decluttering a life overrun by needless things.

docs.lead_paragraph: Researchers are exploring a somewhat controversial link between minor, or subclinical, thyroid problems and some patients’ psychiatric difficulties.

headline.seo: For Some, Psychiatric Troubles May Begin With the Thyroid
headline.main: For Some, Psychiatric Trouble May Start in Thyroid
headline.print_headline: For Some, Psychiatric Trouble May Start in Thyroid

docs.abstract: Researchers are exploring a somewhat controversial link between minor thyroid problems and psychiatric difficulties.
docs.snippet: Researchers are exploring a somewhat controversial link between minor, or subclinical, thyroid problems and some patients’ psychiatric difficulties.

docs.lead_paragraph: Beset by insurance costs and desperate to make sure that drivers pass health tests, trucking companies and industry groups are working to persuade them to change their habits.

headline.seo: A Hard Turn: Big-Rig Drivers Focus on Getting Healthy
headline.main: A Hard Turn: Better Health on the Highway
headline.print_headline: A Hard Turn: Better Health On the Highway

docs.abstract: More truck drivers are choosing to eschew traditionally unhealthy lifestyle of their profession, as trucking companies offer incentives for them to lower blood pressure, stop smoking and lose weight; sedentary nature of job and lack of healthy food options have led to eighty-six percent of truck drivers being overweight or obese, fact that has significantly raised insurance costs for their employers.
docs.snippet: Beset by insurance costs and desperate to make sure that drivers pass health tests, trucking companies and industry groups are working to persuade them to change their habits.

docs.lead_paragraph: Why Mayo Clinic scientists had trouble raising funds for their research on senescent cells.

headline.seo: Research on Senescent Cells Is Denied N.I.H. Grant
headline.main: A Struggle for Financing After a Promising Discovery
headline.print_headline: A Struggle for Financing After a Promising Discovery

docs.abstract: Failure of National Institutes of Health to finance Mayo Clinic's ongoing research into senescent cells and life extension is prime example of how institution's peer-reviewed approval process may be deterring innovation.
docs.snippet: Why Mayo Clinic scientists had trouble raising funds for their research on senescent cells.

docs.lead_paragraph: Senescent cells seem to be a benign by-product of the body’s defense against cancer, but researchers are growing suspicious of their culpability in aging.

headline.seo: In Body’s Shield Against Cancer, a Culprit in Aging May Lurk
headline.main: In Body’s Shield Against Cancer, a Culprit in Aging May Lurk
headline.print_headline: In Body’s Shield Against Cancer, a Culprit in Aging May Lurk

docs.abstract: Study conducted by the Mayo Clinic and published in journal Nature finds that mice tissue remains more youthful and vigorous after it is purged of senescent cells, which linger in body even after they lose ability to divide; although genetic purging method cannot be applied to people, startling result could potentially lead to methods for delaying diseases related to aging.
docs.snippet: Senescent cells seem to be a benign by-product of the body’s defense against cancer, but researchers are growing suspicious of their culpability in aging.

docs.lead_paragraph: “Cancer,” some medical experts say, is an imprecise term that is used too loosely these days.

headline.seo: Cancer by Any Other Name Would Not Be as Terrifying

docs.abstract: Gina Kolata essay notes growing number of medical experts advocate doing away with word cancer for certain conditions that may or may not be potentially fatal; says that cancer has become catch-all term for conditions with wide range of prognoses and is unnecessarily frightening in many cases.
docs.snippet: “Cancer,” some medical experts say, is an imprecise term that is used too loosely these days.

docs.lead_paragraph: High blood pressure and other known risk factors for stroke also increase the risk of developing cognitive problems, even among people who have never had a stroke, a new study finds.

headline.seo: Risk Factors for Stroke Can Also Warn of Cognitive Problems
headline.main: Prognosis: Stroke’s Risk Factors Warn of Mental Harm
headline.print_headline: Prognosis: Stroke’s Risk Factors Warn of Mental Harm

docs.abstract: Study published in journal Neurology finds that risk factors that predict stroke also predict mental impairment, even in people who have never had a stroke; study was led by Frederick W Unverzagt at Indiana University.
docs.snippet: High blood pressure and other known risk factors for stroke also increase the risk of developing cognitive problems, even among people who have never had a stroke, a new study finds.

docs.lead_paragraph: A study found that 49 percent of patients over age 75 were given pain medication, compared with about 65 percent of those under age 75.

headline.seo: In Emergency Rooms, Less Pain Medication for the Elderly
headline.main: Disparities: In the E.R., the Elderly Get Less Pain Relief
headline.print_headline: Disparities: In the E.R., the Elderly Get Less Pain Relief

docs.abstract: Analysis published in journal Annals of Emergency Medicine finds older people who go to an emergency room in pain are less likely to get medication for it than younger people with similar levels of distress; Timothy Platts-Mills of the University of North Carolina, Chapel Hill, is study's lead author
docs.snippet: A study found that 49 percent of patients over age 75 were given pain medication, compared with about 65 percent of those under age 75.

docs.lead_paragraph: Women in the Southeast and Appalachia are found to have the highest levels of markers that signal a risk of heart problems.

headline.seo: Geography Affects Heart Disease Risk, Study Suggests
headline.main: Patterns: Heart Study Suggests Place Matters
headline.print_headline: Patterns: Heart Study Suggests Place Matters

docs.abstract: Study published in journal PLoS One finds increased risk of heart problems for women living in the Southeastern United States, region known as 'stroke belt' for its high incidence of cardiovascular disease; finding is exceptional because trend persisted even after researchers controlled for demographic and lifestyle factors that are commonly thought to be the basis for the 'stroke belt' phenomenon; Cheryl R Clark of Harvard University, study's lead author, hypothesizes that findings may point to economic causes.
docs.snippet: Women in the Southeast and Appalachia are found to have the highest levels of markers that signal a risk of heart problems.
